title: Will Uhuru Kenyatta win Kenya’s August 2017 presidential election?
preds:
Ipsos and Infotrak differ yet again on who will win presidential election
https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/article/2001250012/ipsos-and-infotrak-differ-yet-again-on-who-will-win-presidential-election
Kenyan elections 2017: What you need to know
It will be tough for him but he will do it again pulling every string available.....
He kept several of his promises, owns large media houses and is most likely able to rig the election.
Recent polling seems to suggest Kenyatta is picking up a lead. Additionally, can't rule out the potential for a rigged election.
First-term president. Infrastructural development. Recent polls. Rigging.
I don't think the election will be postponed.
Kenyatta is now trailing his main rival, butcthere is a chanche that the election will be postponed which favours Kenyatta because of deeper pockets

Odinga released documents stating that the military is planning on rigging the election in Uhuru's favor. The military said the document was real, but denied it had to do with rigging, seems odd. However, now I'm increasing my odds more towards Uhuru than they were before.
Busses to voting ballots are already full http://bit.ly/2vNogdS. Odinga needs as high a voter turnout as possible to win, and that is looking less and less likely.
Uhuru lures North Eastern voters with two multi-billion projects

I had it 37% yesterday. However, I just read an article (http://bit.ly/2tDJIjP) on how Odinga pulled a massive crowd in Uhuru's main stronghold during a rally, with many chants of his name. Nobody expected him to get anybody at this rally, so this is a huge plus for Odinga.

Not showing up for debate due to his believing he stood in a position of strength. Basically, he blew it off as not important enough to attend, or why risk a strong position now with a poor debate performance later. (I feel probably the first reason - not important enough)
He is not as popular as he once theoretically was or still believes himself to be.  Never discount the power of intimidation and chicanery, though.

Slight downgrade. CFR's blog notes that the election might be postponed due to ballot printing issues, which might be a boon to the Jubilee as it has more resources at its disposal to get through any delays (https://www.cfr.org/blog-post/polls-tighten-run-kenyas-presidential-election).

Didn't show up to debate
One poll showed he had a lead, yet more in depth reading of the same article describes how his percentages in certain regions may be overstated.
Next poll (that apparently didn't have the seemingly incorrect numbers) had him down by 1% (47% to 46%)
Most undecided voters come from regions not voting for Uhuru, so if the opposition can get large turnout, the odds are not in Uhuru's favor.

-5% downgrade due to:
-increased level of threat of  violence (usually indicates support for opposing candidate, not incumbent)
-polls saying neck and neck but polls can be wrong or misled or ignoring factors in both directions. At any rate, indicates incumbent is struggling

A runoff is looking pretty likely at this point, which will allow the opposition to solidify around Odinga. 60% of Kenyans think the country is headed in the wrong direction according to a poll reported by Bloomberg. Not a favorable number for the incumbent, for sure.

http://www.aljazeera.com/video/news/2017/07/kenya-president-kenyatta-skips-presidential-debate-170725045114754.html
He didn't show up for the debate yesterday, but it probably doesn't matter.  Might have been a nice touch to ask Ivanka to sit in his chair, though.
Gosh, have a look at the recent polls: https://www.tuko.co.ke/247484-second-opinion-poll-raila-lead-uhuru-kenyatta.html
Controverse move from Kenyatta who did NOT show up at the TV debate, yesterday! That's interesting, particularly the spin that will follow from that.

Kenyatta enjoys a small but significant lead in the polls. A series of surveys conducted by different companies using different samples have put him on around 48% of the vote, with Odinga on around 43%. These polls suggest that about 8% of Kenyans remain undecided. This suggests that Odinga can still win, but to do so he will have to capture the vast majority of “floating voters” in the last month of campaigning.

Thx at @Rene and @Khalid. In an earlier comment I pointed out the inaccuracy of the polls (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/506525); besides this, there are no current polls, so we are flying blind. Momentum was, however, detectable for Odinga... The articles posted by Rene and Khalid underscored the volatility of the political game. So, it is not as clear as it might seem...

Kenyatta is a strong candidate and accomplished big projects during his presidency. The latest train services from Nairobi to Mombasa received applauses form Kenyans and also other African nations. He and his party has a clearer vision compared to NASA. I am not sure how things will built up if NASA won. Who will take which seat? The election is already complicated and people would vote for stability and he will win. But I do not underestimate the votes for NASA as there were stories of corruption in the papers. So I say 75% YES

Consensus is now 85%, so the 90% I entered on 19 April looks a little too optimistic, especially after reading @Rene ( http://africanarguments.org/2017/07/10/kenya-2017-elections-will-be-like-none-before-heres-why/ ) and https://www.predictit.org/Contract/5495/Will-Uhuru-Kenyatta-be-re-elected-president-of-Kenya-in-2017#data
Interesting article, explains why this election is different: http://africanarguments.org/2017/07/10/kenya-2017-elections-will-be-like-none-before-heres-why/
Comfortably ahead in opinion polls, reduced by some far fetched talk the election will be postponed
Kenya: Fears of rigging ahead of election

Large pool of challengers vs. an incumbent. President already indicating opposition is attempting to undermine electoral process (http://allafrica.com/stories/201707110217.html). Slight increase with under a month to go to the election.
The only reason it might not happen is force majeure
I notice a lot of his platform is along the lines of a better future, better healthcare, or avowing support for parts of Kenya where he does not have majority support (i.e. non-Kikuyu)
Rising approval rating, but still a small-ish possibility of defeat.

According to The Economist, voter registrations are up dramatically from last time.  Newly registered must be in the cities, mostly Nairobi and Mombasa, where opposition are heavily concentrated.  This could be ominous for Kenyatta, except there are 16 minor candidates, about half of whom are running independently:
https://www.tuko.co.ke/239621-the-full-list-2017-presidential-candidates-uhuru-raila.html

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/kenya-uhuru-kenyatta-pulls-election-debates-170706064308184.html
These folks say it's closer than generally believed.  There is always a pretty good chance of last-minute violence or effective fraud, but even without that Kenyatta is likely to win.  Coming down from 100, though--abundance of caution is the operative principle.
Barring significant election day violence or vote fraud on the part of Odinga supporters (unlikely), Kenyatta will win.

Revising down based on recent opinion polls (http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/06/27/uhuru-still-ahead-of-raila-in-poll_c1586322). Kenyatta is still favored with a month to go, but there appears to be a notable undecided voter pool.

Following Marlowupton
"The number of people registered to vote in Kenyaâ€™s presidential election in August has increased by 36% to almost 20m people compared with the vote in 2013. A large turnout in the bigger cities may improve the chances of opposition parties whose main strongholds are in Nairobi, the capital, and Mombasa."
Incumbent in Africa and Kenya will always be difficult to beat. Despite recent reports of city dwelling voter rolls increasing. Will look to re forecast often if momentum stays with opposition.

Giving Kenyatta an advantage because he is the incumbent, but his popularity is not sky high compared to his opponent. There is a lot of campaigning left to be done between now and the election. Will need to continue updating as the election draws nearer.
Despite the successful change of government in the Gambia this year and Nigeria two years ago, incumbent Kenyan presidents always get re-elected.

- Masai  feel like Kenyatta and Ruto have not listened to them since 2013 (maybe earlier)
- impression that regional politics will colour presidential voting choices against Kenyatta
- lots of press about voters and regional MPs urging ruling party to allow voters to vote for whoever they wish and not tie regional selections to presidential platform. (i.e no to six-piece voting)
- some charges about fake news making it difficult for opposing candidates to run and some jump ship to opposition or run as independents.
- "you are free to vote for who you want as long as you cast your ballot for me and my friend Ruto,” President Kenyatta pleaded." clueless leaders are a big red flag (-5%)
-large demographic of younger voters
- fast, widespread adoption of cells and internet  with lots of young voters relying on internet news which could either mean they avoid mainstream press which seems heavily weighted to support Kenyatta, or mean they are beguiled by fake news which seems to come from Kenyatta's group as well as opposition.
I believe Kenya has some corruption in it, and re-election is therefore very possible if you are the incumbent.

The voting irregularities in the 2013 Kenyan national elections appeared to be real and in favor of Kenyatta.  He is running against the same opponent with the same running mate and with a supreme court precedent on his side.  The pollsters say the race is close, but most fixed elections are close until they are over.  The opposition party has real support among Kenyans, but Kenyatta and his family have been in power long enough to know how to keep it.  I predict Kenyatta will win this upcoming election and more elections in the future.

Interesting to use his twitter feed map and cross reference with news articles on his reception in each town. I think he might be struggling to convince voters in certain regions he has their best interests at heart and not just election hopes, especially among the younger voters (a large demographic). Still, he has the resources to outblitz the competition.

Although Uhuru is the current president, and according to the polls he is still leading, there is growing discontent as people feel their economic conditions have deteriorated: http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/05/31/uhuru-raila-in-tight-race-ipsos-opinion-poll-shows_c1571200. The trend seems to be going against Uhuru but more information is needed to make a better judgement.

Most forecasters are overconfident on this question... the race tightens and resembles regarding this much more the US Presidential Elections 2016, and the polls are less accurate than in the US... but still many are more than 90 percent sure Kenyatta will win. Good luck!

The counties won by Odinga currently have 10,547,913 registered voters, compared to 7,556,609 in counties where Kenyatta prevailed. This means that Odinga still has a chance, but in order to win he will have to run up the numbers in his strongholds, while at the same time getting more of his voters to the polls. Given the 2017 registration numbers, and if the turnout and vote share patterns witnessed in 2013 were to hold this year, then Kenyatta would still win with 8,000,936 votes (51.5%) against Odinga’s 7,392,439 votes (47.6%).
https://kenopalo.com/2017/05/26/by-the-numbers-a-look-at-the-2017-presidential-election-in-kenya/
It seems likely that Kenyatta will win the 2017 election, even if facing a runoff, but 2022 may be a different story.

The politics and controversies of Kenya's 2017 general election
http://www.dw.com/en/the-politics-and-controversies-of-kenyas-2017-general-election/g-38601251
Incumbency seems to be key, but the sample size is very low.

Odinga has failed to garner enough support to make a big political swing. Kenyatta will push his "successes" hard leading up to August and will attempt to be the "sensible" candidate for stability in the country.
ithink  Raila Odinga will win the 2017 general elections
Names have power and that is power in that country
Strong opinion polls, African elections have stronger than normal incumbency bias

No president has ever lost when being put up for initial re election. There is too much investment in international partnerships, a heightened level of fear and no departure from previous voting structures / messages to consider that this is as close to an election "certainty" as is likely to be in Kenya.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/04/odinga-run-presidency-opposition-coalition-170427142741901.html
Remember how well Adlai Stevenson did when he ran against the same guy twice?  Well, Odinga will now be running against the same guy three times.

According to a new poll, if the elections were held today, Uhuru would get 40 per cent of the Presidential votes and Raila 29 per cent.
https://www.ipsos.com/en/kenya-2017-poll-two-horse-race?language_content_entity=en

He runs the government.  He is not facing term limits.   His party controls patronage on a large scale.
How could he not win?
Incumbent president who must step down in 2012 against a three time opposition loser means that Kenyatta should win.

-Largest land owner of largest tribe (first to market strength, harder for smaller guys to push off the podium)
-Incumbent so very familiar with political landscape, deep relationships, knowledge of political infrastructure
-Father, led country, considered a hero for standing up to colonial UK - elder lineage continuity Important to Kenyans
-Kenyatta is wily, took on ICC, domestic opponents with some success
-formed an alliance rule with opponent which was solid to beat an international threat 
- seems willing to take power by force if need be
-Last election was relatively peaceful so Kenyans might be hoping for a similar transition to power
- no likely rival in race
Following @acohen cause that's good base rate information.
I know its a small sample size but no Kenyan president has lost reelection. Also, he seems to be generally popular, certainly more popular than his opponents.
Polls give him a significant, though below 50% advantage, that brings down to a very likely win
At this point, it's not easy to see who can beat him, but time marches.
